Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen some of you 
may remember my video for ginger soy chicken that

I posted a while back now that recipe was inspired 
by my grandmother's gai kem which is what she

does with her left over poached worship chicken 
now which means that that chicken is actually

cooked twice so for that video I simplified it so 
that you only have to cook the chicken ones and

you can have it on a Wednesday night if you wanted 
to but I just came back from a trip to Thailand

and I had her original guy came again and I just 
could not get over it with what a difference that

extra cooking step makes so today I'm going 
to show you guy cam that is not inspired by

my grandmother's recipe this is my grandmother's 
recipe so if you've got the time definitely check

it out it really is an entirely different dish 
and so delicious let's get started so we're gonna

start by poaching the chicken so at this point 
what my grandmother is normally trying to make

is Hainanese chicken rice and so I have a recipe 
for that too if you want to but then we never eat

all of the poached chicken so then the leftover 
host chicken gets turned into okay Kim so now

we're just going to poach our chicken and directly 
puts it into a guide Kim so I've got here those

parts instead of a whole chicken just to save us 
some time it won't affect the end result make sure

it's bone-in this part is very very important I 
like to do a mix of dark meat and white meat so

that it kind of mimics the whole chicken you get 
a mix of different textures and your end result

so now I'm going to add some water just enough 
to cover the chicken now aromatic speaking of

I'm going to add some ginger into this poaching 
liquid and also some garlic which I've crushed

so they're broken so all the aroma can come out 
this next step is optional if you have it throw

it in if not doesn't really matter I'm just using 
the tops of my lemongrass which I have left over

from a different recipe so just going to throw 
those in the top half lemon grass is quite weak

in terms of flavor so it's just going to add a 
very light citrusy aroma and some salt we want to

season the chicken at this point as well and I'm 
going to let this poach very gently so the water

shouldn't be boiling if it has any bubbles at 
all it should be very gentle bubbles because you

want the chicken to cook us evenly as possible if 
you've got a thermometer 175 180 degree Fahrenheit

is great so keep an eye on that all right so my 
chicken is done and so for me that took about 20

minutes now this liquid right here is absolutely 
delicious so what I would do is take this liquid

and cook your rice with it in fact you can make 
Hainanese chicken rice at this point with this

broth use it in soup it's so delicious or just 
serve it skim off all the scum and then serve it

along with this meal as a little bit of broth if 
you'd like now I'm going to let the chicken cool

a little bit just so I can handle it and this 
step by the way you can do like days in advance

just put the chicken in the fridge and cook it 
up whenever you're ready now that the chicken

is cool enough to handle and we're just going to 
pair it into bite-sized pieces and yes definitely

tear it because you want those irregular pieces 
especially the small little edges because those

pieces are the best part so I just pair it up and 
by the way at this point if you've realized oh my

gosh I undercooked my chicken a little bit don't 
worry because you're gonna cook it again right so

this is the one part where you don't have to be 
super careful with it so yeah I just tear it up

into you know sir fry friendly pieces especially 
once you get to the bone and you get like small

pieces like this these become like really good and 
when you get a long piece of chicken like this and

it's hard to pull it apart with the grain you 
get a meat cleaver yes my new fine from Thailand

and it's perfect look you just cut it up alright 
this is the part where it gets easy as I said if

you have left over poached chicken say you made 
Hainanese chicken rice you can start from here

you can make this step in advance so it doesn't 
have to be something that takes a long time so

I've kind of walked in here I'm going to cook 
up some garlic and ginger in the little bit of

vegetable oil woohoo garlic and ginger and yes I 
added when the oil is not hot that way it heats up

together with the oil and I don't risk burning the 
garlic I'm actually going to switch to my wooden

spatula because it's not as loud there we go I 
don't like the shape of this one as much it's a

little too this angles a little too high but for 
the sake of our ears so ones as small as pieces

of garlic starts to brown I'm going to go in with 
palm sugar and I want to add the palm sugar now so

that it dissolves completely if you don't have 
palm sugar you can just use a white or light

brown sugar as well and so the flavor profile is 
going to be salty sweet make sure your he's not

too high at this point otherwise your sugar won't 
melt before your garlic is burned and of course

you can press the sugar lumps down this only a 
problem if you're a little if you're better with

the chopping of the sugar I was obviously lazy and 
I just pounded it in my mortar and pestle okay so

now the chicken goes in boom give it a quick toss 
and this heat will start to render out some of the

chicken fat so you definitely don't want to add 
too much oil in the very beginning and if your

chicken is fridge cold because you've made it in 
advance definitely you want to make sure you give

it enough time to heat up right okay so now I'm 
going to go in with my seasoning it is incredibly

simple it's going to go into some soy sauce and 
just a dash of black soy sauce for some color and

also use dark soy booboo so now Oh black pepper I 
really like black pepper in this you can do white

if you want and now would you believe it this 
is pretty much done in terms of ingredients but

I want to keep cooking this until all that liquid 
dries up and the sauce penetrates the chicken and

that's how you get iconic grandma is it dry when 
it's done and I like to let one to start to dry

I like to let it sit a little bit without stirring 
for the chicken starts to get a little caramelized

and all the tiny little shreds of chicken almost 
become super caramelized and super good yeah see

it gets nice browning there and give it another 
flip let it fit one more time yes that is exactly

what we're going for and now it's nice and dry 
and caramelize that's it I'll keep and you're

done look at this now I'm going to just finish 
it off with some chopped cilantro and I forgot

to mention while I was cooking it if this is your 
first time definitely give it a pace for saltiness

because as you can see because it's so dry your 
the amount of soy sauce that you use will matter

a lot because everything is sucked onto here so I 
often find that sometimes if my chickens a little

bigger than normal I need to add just a pinch of 
salt you have to add soy sauce just you know once

it's dry add a little pinch of salt and you'll 
kick it back out so definitely give that a quick

taste as well I always serve this with rice and 
if I had been more organized I would have made

rice using that chicken broth but I wasn't that 
organized so we're going to use jasmine rice as

an option because normally my grandmother makes 
this using leftover Hainanese chicken rice I

always have the dipping sauce from the Hainanese

I think it's really good the chicken is good

this is a flavor of home my home specifically
